article: Happiness is like a pebble  dropped  into a pool to bring  _  ever-widening circle of ripples . As Stevenson has said, being happy is a duty. There  _  no exact definition of the word happiness. Happy people are happy  _  all sorts of reasons. The key is not wealth or physical health, since we find beggars, invalids and so-called failures,  _  are extremely happy. Being happy is a sort of unexpected dividend. But  staying  happy is a total triumph of soul and character. It is not selfish to work hard for it. It is, indeed, a duty to ourselves and others. Being  _  is like an infectious illness.  _  causes people to shrink away from the sufferer. He soon  _  himself alone, sad and frustrated. There is, however, a cure so simple; if you don't feel happy, pretend to be! It works.  Before long  you will find that instead of driving people away, you attract them. You discover how deeply rewarding it is to be the  _  of wider and wider circles of good will. Then the make-believe becomes a  _  . You own the peace of mind, and can forget yourself in being of service to  _  . Being happy, once it is realized as a duty and started as a  _  , opens doors into unimaginable gardens crowded  _  grateful friends.
